Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An Innovative Treatment Process for Nitrate Removal from Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is the development of a low-cost process to mitigating nitrate, a ubiquitous pollutant that is steadily eroding the quality and availability of safe potable water all around the world. This novel process combines and sequences electrochemistry, aqueous chemical reactions, solid oxide formation and surface adsorption processes into a simple continuous-flow unit to achieve high levels of nitrate removal; optimization will be guided by computational techniques that lend themselves to discovery of new materials that may also demonstrate breakthrough potential for other critical fields such as fuel treatment and large scale energy storage. The project offers an opportunity to apply interdisciplinary solutions to complex societal problems and will yield a self-contained unit, inexpensive to build and operate, scalable, modular and reliable.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to develop an inexpensive water treatment module for selective removal of nitrate from aqueous media. The module employs a novel sequence of electrochemically controlled processes to promote in situ formation and ripening of metal hydrous oxide crystals, with documented adsorptive effectiveness, readily separating them from continuously flowing water. The primary objectives of this project are refining and addressing the high risk aspects of this methodology, merging field experience with concepts from published papers, sequencing processes and regulating conditions in novel ways, enhancing adsorption properties while mitigating interferences by oxyanions. The technology will advance understanding of metal hydrous oxides and the kinetics of their formation, which may well inform creation of other inexpensive processes for simultaneous removal of multiple problematic pollutants, potentially recovering them for commercial re-use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes: Contamination of fresh water worldwide is increasing at an accelerating rate. One of the most common contaminants today is nitrate (NO3-), a highly soluble anion that is both difficult and costly to remove from water, posing risks to human health and significantly altering the natural nitrogen cycle. This project’s objective was to complete development of a water treatment method that enables an inexpensive, resource-efficient, reliable, scalable, continuous-process system for nitrate removal. This novel method forms adsorbent iron hydrous oxide media using electrochemistry, which stimulates targeted nitrate adsorption, and filtration or settling separates the iron precipitate out of the water. This project has significantly advanced the state of the art and developed the technology, already proven to remove nitrates and with strong potential for removal of other problematic pollutants from water. The project built on prior process development, prototype testing and data analysis, validating prior research, eliminating process interferences and developing practical apparatus design applicable to both portable field implementation and scaled-up infrastructure installations. The project did succeed in reaching removal rates in the range of 42%-58%, but not on a consistent basis; however, the project team believes that, with further work, it has defined a high-probability pathway to achieving the ultimate goal of consistent removals of 60%-85%.

Intellectual Merit: The project applied transformative research techniques to completing development of this novel approach to removing contaminants from water in a continuous process.  With over six years of prior independent proprietary development, this project, run on live effluent from a wastewater treatment plant, has advanced the scientific understanding of this multi-disciplinary method, combining electrochemistry, surface chemistry, basic chemistry and physics, using scalable and inexpensive electrochemical processes to control aqueous chemical reactions and oxide surface formations for targeted ion removal. This project was specifically oriented to the high risk aspects of developing this technology, optimizing ferric particle formation for selective nitrate adsorption by characterizing and systematically controlling and balancing inputs and competing processes. The ultimate objective of the project was to achieve consistent nitrate removals of at least 60%, thereby enabling commercial application of an economical, versatile methodology. We did not reach that goal, but we did elucidate many poorly understood processes and reactions, thereby discerning a high-probability path to achieving the 60% goal.  The techniques developed and refined n this project merge field experience with concepts from published research papers, sequencing processes and regulating conditions in a novel way, thereby promoting selective adsorption and removal of monovalent anions while preventing interferences by multivalent oxyanions. When successful, this approach should lead to the creation of an array of inexpensive processes for simultaneous, targeted removals of a range of specific problematic pollutants and potential recovery and re-use of the pollutants as nutrients. 

Broader/Commercial Impact: The ever-rising level of nitrates limits the availability of groundwater as drinking water and is a major cause of eutrophication in surface waters. Progress here is vital, where known solutions are unaffordable or unreliable: most sources of treated wastewater are discharging an excess of nitrogen to the environment, with no affordable methods commercially available for restricting total nitrogen output to harmless levels. This project has confirmed that this system is an effective process, with no obvious limits to scalability, and with a very low apparent cost of ownership and operation, a modest footprint, and by-products that can be re-purposed with beneficial environmental impacts. It could be used for virtually any channeled water source with elevated levels of nitrates. While its science is complex, it is sequential and interlinked, so the entire process, properly tuned, may be controlled with one input: electrical current. Operational simplicity, scalability and versatility indicate it will be practical for use in both advanced and developing countries, making scarce but tainted sources of drinking water usable once again. This project, with the progress it has made, provides a pathway to scoring societal benefits -- improving the quality of fresh water available for human use; it has also advanced the scientific understanding of how potentially to use harmless, commonly available materials in combination with hydroxyls for remediation of harmful pollutants. The project engaged professors and graduate students at Stony Brook University for advisory, scientific and field research support and worked extensively with the NYS Center for Clean Water Technolgy. While this project was focused specifically on the electrochemical production and control of iron hydrous oxide for wastewater treatment, the science and method may also be broadly applicable to critical fields of industry such as fuel desulfurization and low temperature CO2 sequestration.
